column6: World history from early human societies through the mid-17th century.
Continuation of HIST 11050. World history from mid-17th century to the present.

column2: HISTORY OF THE UNITED STATES: THE FORMATIVE PERIOD
column6: A survey of United States history through 1877.

column2: HISTORY OF THE UNITED STATES: THE MODERN PERIOD
column6: A survey of United States history since 1877.
Survey of one of the greatest political and military events in history, focusing especially on causes, major personalities and chief political, ideological, moral, scientific and diplomatic aspects.
Survey of medieval and early modern England. Topics include Norman Conquest, medieval culture and society, Reformation, Age of Elizabeth, English Revolution.
Survey of national development from the Glorious Revolution through the Second World war, with special attention to leaders, prominent individuals and problems of change.

column4: Junior standing or special approval of instructor.
column6: Examination of the historical and contemporary roles of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

column2: HISTORY AND SOCIETY OF MODERN GREECE
column6: Study of modern Greece concentrating on political, economic, cultural and societal developments since 1821.
Survey of French history from 1815 to the present. Topics include industrialization, republicanism and revolution, the experience of war and defeat, empire and decolonization.

column2: HISTORY OF WOMEN IN THE UNITED STATES
column6: An exploration of the political, economic, social, intellectual, and cultural forces that have shaped women’s lives, women’s thought, perceptions of womanhood, and feminism for 1607 to the present in what is now the United States.

column2: AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY: SLAVERY TO FREEDOM
column6: Survey of African American history from the colonial period to 1877. Course provides a general knowledge of the social, political and cultural history of African Americans from colonial times to the end of the Reconstruction.

column2: AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY: RECONSTRUCTION TO THE PRESENT
column6: Survey of African American history from 1877 to the present. Course provides a general knowledge of the social, political and cultural history of African Americans from the end of the Reconstruction to the present.
General survey of evolution of Chinese civilization from the Bronze Age to the rise of communism.
Study of the causes, evolution and effects of warfare in Vietnam from 1946 to 1975 with special attention to colonialism, nationalism, communism and American intervention.
Describes history of the Zionist movement from religious, ideological and political viewpoints and the relationship between Zionism and the state of Israel.
A survey of Islamic civilization in Middle Eastern context from the earliest days to the present.

column2: ANCIENT AND EARLY MEDIEVAL JEWISH HISTORY
column6: Deals with the ancient and early medieval Jewish history from approximately 2000 B.C. to approximately 1200 A.D.

column2: LATE MEDIEVAL AND MODERN JEWISH HISTORY
column6: Survey of Jewish history in Europe and the middle east from the age of the crusades to the 20th century.
Survey of cultural, political, social and economic history of Africa from antiquity to European conquest. Emphasis on precolonial.

Focuses on 20th-century Latin America and the efforts by social classes and their political leaderships to overcome obstacles of underdevelopment. Emphasis on Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico, Cuba and Central America.
Examines Latin America from pre-colonial times to the late 19th century. Lectures emphasize political and economic questions while readings focus on social history.

column4: History major and 6 hours in history.
column6: Introduction to the study and practice of historical writing including historical methods, historiography, primary and secondary source research, critical analysis of documentary sources, historical reasoning and the preparation of written reports. Emphasis on developing effective communication skills and research procedures, record-keeping, citation, and bibliography. Prepares students to do advanced work in history.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN UNITED STATES HISTORY
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Special course in the history of the United States, the subject and topic of which varies by term and instructor. Precise titles and descriptions to be inserted in the Schedule of Classes.

(Repeatable for credit) Special course in the history of Europe since 1500, the subject and topic of which varies by term and instructor. Precise titles and descriptions to be inserted in the Schedule of Classes.

(Repeatable for credit) Special course in the history of one or more of the following: the ancient and medieval worlds, Africa, Asia, Latin America, or the Middle East, the subject and topic of which varies by term and instructor. Precise titles and descriptions to be inserted in the Schedule of Classes.
(Repeatable for credit)Student internship at an institution related to the history major (e.g., historical society, museum, archives, historic preservation organization).

column2: AMERICAN CULTURAL HERITAGE: THE ARTS AND SOCIETY
column4: Junior standing and one prior course in history.
column6: Examination of music, painting and literature in their cultural contexts during four periods of American history. American studies methodology and interdisciplinary thought.
A survey of public history including: archives, editing, museums and historical agency administration; historic preservation and related skill areas (e.g. artifact analysis, oral history).
Survey of Greek history from the Bronze Age to the rise of Macedonia and Alexander the Great.
(Cross-listed with CLAS 41006, CLAS 51006, HIST 51006 and HIST 71006) A survey of Roman history from its beginnings to the fall of the Roman empire.
Survey of major political, social and cultural developments of Europe from the fourth through 10th centuries.
Survey of political, social and cultural developments of Europe from 11th through 13th centuries.
Analysis of the various factors leading Europe from a rural, feudal, ecclesiastical society to one characterized by urbanism, trade, secularism and the state.
Comprehensive course dealing with the religious, political, economic and social change accompanying the religious upheavals of the 16th century.
This course will analyze those political, economic, social, religious and intellectual factors leading to economic crisis and civil wars in Europe.
Focus on industrialization and social transformation, political upheavals, intellectual thought, nationalism and foreign policy in Great Britain, France, Prussia and Austria.
Special attention paid to the two world wars, Bolshevik Revolution, rise of fascism and fate of European Jewry.
Survey of European political, economic, social and cultural developments since 1945.
Focuses on the impact of industrialization, the dilemma of the German left, the rise of Nazism and the emergence of two German states after 1945.
Study of the entire imperial period, with focus on modernization, state institutions, nationalities, social groups and estates, economy, politics and ideologies, and elite and popular culture.

Focus on 1917 revolutions; Civil War; nationalities question; NEP, collectivization; Great Terror; World War II; Cold War; Soviet Foreign policy and culture; Perestroika and post-Soviet economic, political and ideological changes.

column2: POLITICS, CULTURE AND SOCIETY OF 20TH-CENTURY EUROPE
column6: Political, social and cultural change in Europe during the twentieth century. Topics include violence, war, revolution, economic crises, and social and political changes.
Major patterns of thought and behavior among Spanish, French and English expansionists; English colonization to 1714.
Cultural development of English colonies; Great War for Empire; American Revolution and Constitution.
Study of the founding and development of the American nation, especially the periods of Jefferson and Jackson.

Examination of the theories and practices of fascist movements and regimes in twentieth-century Europe utilizing a variety of perspectives. Organized primarily thematically instead of geographically with readings and discussions based on historiographical and critical analyses.

column2: THE UNITED STATES: THE WESTWARD MOVEMENT
column6: The process of settlement from its beginnings; consequences for American history.
Differences within the United States, including the controversy over slavery; the Civil War in all its aspects.
Controversy during and after the Civil War as to racial and sectional relationships; the post- Reconstruction compromises and their undoing.

Major currents of the period: social background of the early republic; religious development; impact of the frontier, abolition. This course may be used to satisfy the university diversity Requirement.
Development of social Darwinism, racism, pragmatism, popular arts.

column2: WAR AND SOCIETY IN THE UNITED STATES FROM 1607 THROUGH 1865
column6: An examination of the impact of conflict and the military upon the society, culture, economy and diplomacy of the United States. Topics include colonial Indian wars, the Revolutionary War, the War of 1812, the Mexican-American War and the Civil War.

column2: WAR AND SOCIETY IN THE UNITED STATES FROM 1865 TO THE PRESENT
column6: An examination of the impact of conflict and the military on the society, culture, economy and diplomacy of the United States. Topics include the frontier Army, the Spanish-American War and empire in the Pacific, the two world wars, the Cold War and the War on Terror.

Examines the coming together of people from five continents to the United States and provides an overview of shifting patterns of migration both coerced and free to the United States. Starting in the colonial era, when slaves and servants typified the migration to America, this course then follows the migrations of pre-industrial, industrial, and post-industrial immigrants, their reception by American institutions and natives, and their efforts to construct communities in a new country.
The history of U.S. foreign policy from the 1920s on with special emphasis on the evolving role of America as a world power.
Major political, economic, social, cultural and diplomatic events from the crisis of the 1890s through the first World War.

column2: NEW ERA THROUGH WORLD WAR: THE UNITED STATES, 1920-1945
column6: Major political, economic, social, cultural and diplomatic events from the new era of the 1920s through the second World War.

Examines everyday life and culture, assesses the degree to which presidents and their administrations are the reflections of their constituencies, and evaluates the significant events and themes of U.S. history since 1945.

column2: COLLOQUIUM: SAINTS, MONKS, AND THE MEDIEVAL COMMUNITY
column6: Investigates major religious institutions that shaped medieval European society and the impact on popular piety.
Disintegration of the Chinese empire amid Western challenge and internal disorder and the subsequent rise of communism.
General survey of the development of Japan from a loose confederation of clans to a modern industrial state.

column2: THE HOLOCAUST: THE DESTRUCTION OF EUROPEAN JEWRY, 1938-1945
column6: Analysis of those political, economic, social and intellectual factors leading to systematic destruction of European Jewry during World War II.
Analysis of the causes of Revolution in France, political, ideological and social conflict in the construction of French democracy expansion of the revolution outside of France.

column2: THE SIXTIES: A THIRD WORLD VIEW
column6: Examines the political, social and cultural upheaval of the 1960s in Latin America, Africa and Asia.
Examination of 20th-century revolutions in Latin America, Africa and Asia focusing on ideologies and political leadership.

Focuses on the social, cultural and political life of the African population of Latin America, from 19th century slaves to shantytown dwellers of megacities such as Rio de Janiero. Topics include black resistance to racism, race mixture in multicultural societies, and how employment, political participation and family organization empowered the lives of Afro-Latin women.
Study of important issues in the history of China and Japan through reading and discussing major works pertinent to the issues selected.

The colloquium addresses the experiences of European women from the Enlightenment to the present. Using primary sources and recent scholarship, students examine the relationship between women and state formation, industry, sexuality, empire, socialism, war, welfare, migration and feminism.

Political, social, economic and cultural developments from the 9th-17th centuries, particularly the nature of political organization, the Mongol impact, the role of the church and religious life in pre-Petrine Russia.
Consideration of distinctive features of Victorian England including class structure, ideas, manners, politics, foreign affairs, empire.
Reading, discussion and written reviewing of important works on the period.

column2: COLLOQUIUM IN AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY TO 1877
column6: This colloquium specializes in African American history prior to 1877, with emphasis on historiographical literature of the period.

column2: COLLOQUIUM IN AFRICAN AMERICAN HISTORY SINCE 1877
column6: This colloquium specializes in African American history after 1877, with emphasis on historiographical literature of the period.

column4: History major and senior standing and HIST 32050 with C or higher.
column6: (Repeatable for credit)History majors complete a significant work of original research based on primary sources. Topics vary by instructor. Enrollment limited to senior history majors.

A survey of public history including: archives; editing, museums and historical agency administration; historic preservation; and related skill areas (e.g. artifact analysis, oral history).

Special focus on integrating non-Western sources and points of view into the world history curriculum, preparation of world history syllabus and justification of selected readings and topics, mastery of on-line and in-class technologies to deliver world history materials.
(Cross-listed with CLAS 41006, CLAS 51006, HIST 41006 and HIST 71006) A survey of Roman history from its beginnings to the Fall of the Roman Empire.
A survey of the major political, social and cultural developments of Europe from the fourth through the tenth century.
A survey of political, social and cultural developments of Europe from the eleventh through the thirteenth century.
This course will analyze those political, economic, social, religious and intellectual factors leading to economic crisis and civil wars in Europe.
Special attention paid to the two World Wars, Bolshevik Revolution, rise of Fascism and fate of European Jewry.
Survey of European political, economic, social and cultural developments since 1945.
Focuses on the impact of industrialization, the dilemma of the German left, the rise of Nazism, and the emergence of two German states after 1945.

Focus on 1917 revolutions, civil war, nationalities question, NEP, collectivization, Great Terror, World War II, Cold War, Soviet foreign policy and culture, Perestroika, and post-Soviet economic, political, and ideological changes.

Topics include black resistance to racism, race mixture in multicultural societies, and how employment, political participation and family organization empowered the lives of Afro-Latin women.

Using primary sources and recent scholarship, students examine the relationship between women and state formation, industry, sexuality, empire, socialism, war, welfare, migration and feminism.

column6: Introduction to recent trends in the writing of European and comparative western religious history.
